title: Simple To Use, but Lacks a Key Feature
comment: Bitcoin Wallet happened to be the first application that I tried. Of the 15+ bitcoin wallets I have tested, this is one of the easiest to use for beginners. My major complaint (and really my only complaint) about this wallet is that it lacks a "Max" button when sending bitcoins.  From the send Bitcoin view, there is no way to view your current balance or to set the application to send every possible bitcoin to a new location.  For day to day use, this is not a huge problem, but it is a problem when you are testing multiple systems or when you decide to cash out of bitcoin altogether.  I have now closed and deleted at least two Bitcoin Wallet applications that have between 0.00000001 BTC and 0.000100 BTC still unspent. With the private keys now gone, these coins are "lost" forever and can never be spent by anyone.   Having a Max spend feature is a critical component to protecting the health of the Bitcoin economy so these little parts of coins do not become lost forever.
Just use the "empty wallet" option to empty out wallets. No need to throw away Satoshis.

title: works great
comment: android entropy bug fixed several versions ago, this app works properly, creates new receiving and change addresses properly unlike single-address app bitcoinspinner.  Backup & restore worked great for me. A potential problem: if you device gets stolen or borrowed, someone could immediately spend all the btc in your wallet with you unable to prevent that.  This app could use a password entry encrypting the private keys, forcing the password to be entered to allow spending or new address generating. That'd give me the chance to get back home and restore a backup and send btc out of the Android Bitcoin Wallet so that the person who stole my device would never get my btc that was stored in it. A less desirable alternative: have the ability to remote wipe your device, but an adversary who knows what they're doing can easily get around that. (pop battery out before phone gets the signal to wipe, disable radio, boot up, start up bitcoin wallet, save backup file, export file to their PC.  import it to their own device, steal your coins.)
A spending password is planned.

title: Need some improvement but very good
comment: App has good features and it's executed nicely. It's fast and intuitive. All works fine except one thing, it doesn't disconnect. App should disconnect when it's closed but after exiting, and even removing from the list of recent apps, I can still see status bar message saying that I'm connected to 6 peers. I left home, switched to mobile data and app was still active for the next 5 hours. Didn't use much data, around 40KB, but still this was unnecessary battery and data drain. Until this is fixed I can't give it more than 3 stars. Other than that developers did a good job.

Don't worry, the app will disconnect intelligently. I've had one user report of the connectivity indicator staying although the app was disconnected, but I could not reproduce the issue. If your indicator constantly stays although your blockchain is caught up, its a bug and please mail me.

title: Why the auto fee?
comment: I realize its only ~.01$ at the moment, but still, there is zero indication of the fee until you look at your balance after you send coins. I transfer a few micro-btc from my tablet to my phone on a regular basis depending on what im doing and having to pay a fee to do that every time eats away at my balance and is very annoying. Can you please re-enable the option for not including a fee if you dont want to include one?  update: I appreciate your response, but you havent addressed the complaint about there not being any sort of indication there is a fee being charged. Please include some sort of notification on the send screen that adds the fee automatically so you dont have to keep switching back and forth.

The transaction fee is a well known fact. If you want to change that, you need to address the whole Bitcoin community (I suggest bitcointalk.org). The app calculates the exact minimum needed. Going below that minimum causes stuck transactions and I don't want to support that any more.

title: Background resources usage!
comment: Catches up with the block chain on the background without any user control over it. Wastes data unless system-limited not to consume data on background (not available on older OS versions or on WiFi). Wastes battery (just reported it to waste 19% of it). The dev actively rejects this being an issue (see the replies on other comments).

System level restriction is the way to go here, because you might want to restrict other apps in the same way (after all, lots of apps use *much* more resources).

Use Options > Settings > Data usage.

Spending from a paper wallet is an inherently dangerous operation, so its not supported by the Bitcoin network. This is why this app currently can't support it. The app always determines the correct minimum fee for you, no need to worry about that.

comment: It's gotten better than previous versions, but it still has a flaw.  It wastes airtime/battery, by self-activating itself in the background at periodic times and whenever your phone reboots.  I, and many others, really wish it wouldn't do this, but author disagrees.  Other than that big flaw, this is best Bitcoin wallet for Android... and thus for any phone, since Apple doesn't allow Bitcoin wallets at all on iOS!  Four stars (would be five if author allowed background activity to be turned off).

It was never possible to disable background sync from within the app. Luckily, data usage is negliable nowadays.

If you feel like experimenting, try using "Restrict background data" in the "Data usage" Android settings. Let me know if that causes a problem (other than not receiving transactions any more).

title: Multiple addresses confusion
comment: I have just installed this on my device and created two addresses. I transferred some BTC to one address and some to the second one. I thought the wallet will show the individual balance associated with each of those addresses, but I was wrong. Bitcoin wallet is now showing me one single balance for the BTC associated with these two addresses. My question is, I assume that since I cannot send BTC out of each address for more than what it owns in the address (for example, address A - 0.5 BTC, address B - 1.5 BTC), I cannot send 1 BTC out of address A. But now since bitcoin wallet is mixing the two together I am unable to find out how much BTC each of them own... Or there is some other way that I am not aware of? Confusing...

You're right, Bitcoin Wallet does not separate between addresses. It's all just one wallet, just like your physical one. Bitcoin Wallet will automatically pick the addresses to spend from (it will also mix if needed). It's planned to manage multiple wallets, but it'll take some time to arrive.

The advice to "only install apps you trust" is pretty much impossible on Android these days, I can never be sure some app won't read my wallet and steal my money. Encrypting the private keys would prevent that. Safety and security is a *must* with Bitcoin!
This is a common misunderstanding. Wallet encryption would not help with malicious apps, as those can just wait until you enter the passphrase. It just protects in the case of loosing your phone.
